api_token.description:
The access key for API operations. You can retrieve this
from the Twingate Admin Console ([documentation](https://docs.twingate.com/docs/api-overview)).
Alternatively, this can be specified using the TWINGATE_API_TOKEN environment variable.

network.description:
Your Twingate network ID for API operations.
You can find it in the Admin Console URL, for example:
`autoco.twingate.com`, where `autoco` is your network ID
Alternatively, this can be specified using the TWINGATE_NETWORK environment variable.

url.description:
The default is 'twingate.com'
This is optional and shouldn't be changed under normal circumstances.

id.description: Autogenerated ID of the Connector, encoded in base64

name.description: Autogenerated name of the Connector (can't be changed)

remote_network_id.description: The ID of the Remote Network to attach the Connector to

block.description: Connectors provide connectivity to Remote Networks. This resource type will create the Connector in the Twingate Admin Console, but in order to successfully deploy it, you must also generate Connector tokens that authenticate the Connector with Twingate. For more information, see Twingate's [documentation](https://docs.twingate.com/docs/understanding-access-nodes).

access_token.description: The Access Token of the parent Connector

connector_id.description: The ID of the parent Connector

keepers.description: Arbitrary map of values that, when changed, will trigger recreation of resource. Use this to automatically rotate Connector tokens on a schedule.

refresh_token.description: The Refresh Token of the parent Connector

block.description: This resource type will generate tokens for a Connector, which are needed to successfully provision one on your network. The Connector itself has its own resource type and must be created before you can provision tokens.

id.description: The ID of the Remote Network

name.description: The name of the Remote Network

block.description: A Remote Network represents a single private network in Twingate that can have one or more Connectors and Resources assigned to it. You must create a Remote Network before creating Resources and Connectors that belong to it. For more information, see Twingate's [documentation](https://docs.twingate.com/docs/remote-networks).

address.description: The Resource's IP/CIDR or FQDN/DNS zone

group_ids.description: List of Group IDs that have permission to access the Resource, cannot be generated by Terraform and must be retrieved from the Twingate Admin Console or API

id.description: Autogenerated ID of the Resource, encoded in base64

remote_network_id.description: Remote Network ID where the Resource lives

policy.description: Whether to allow all ports or restrict protocol access within certain port ranges: Can be `RESTRICTED` (only listed ports are allowed) or `ALLOW_ALL`

ports.description: List of port ranges between 1 and 65535 inclusive, in the format `100-200` for a range, or `8080` for a single port

policy.description: Whether to allow all ports or restrict protocol access within certain port ranges: Can be `RESTRICTED` (only listed ports are allowed) or `ALLOW_ALL`

ports.description: List of port ranges between 1 and 65535 inclusive, in the format `100-200` for a range, or `8080` for a single port

block.description: Restrict access to certain protocols and ports. By default or when this argument is not defined, there is no restriction, and all protocols and ports are allowed.

Resources in Twingate represent servers on the private network that clients can connect to. Resources can be defined by IP, CIDR range, FQDN, or DNS zone. For more information, see the Twingate [documentation](https://docs.twingate.com/docs/resources-and-access-nodes).
